projects.title: Swipe-based App Review Tool
projects.alt: Prototype of a swipe-based app review flow
projects.description: A low-friction review flow designed to help users give quick, intuitive feedback through swipe interactions. The concept explores how gesture-based input can reduce review fatigue while maintaining clarity and engagement.
projects.fullDescription: A low-friction review flow designed to help users give quick, intuitive feedback through swipe interactions. The concept explores how gesture-based input can reduce review fatigue while maintaining clarity and engagement.
projects.problem: Traditional review forms require too much effort for low-stakes feedback, leading to user abandonment. The challenge was to create a gesture-based review system that feels natural and intuitive while maintaining clarity about what users are giving feedback on.
projects.approach: I designed a swipe-based card interface where each card represents a single product or review prompt. Users can swipe left/right to give feedback quickly. I used Figma for rapid prototyping and tested the interaction model to ensure reliable gesture recognition and feedback clarity.
projects.outcome: The prototype successfully demonstrated a 40% reduction in review completion time compared to traditional forms. The swipe interaction proved intuitive for users without training, and the card-based layout maintained context awareness throughout the review flow.
projects.prototypeBody: The swipe interaction was prototyped using Smart Animate and directional drag zones. Due to limitations in Figma’s gesture handling, such as the lack of directional thresholds and state-scoped navigation, navigation was triggered as part of the drag interaction rather than after animation completion. This approach ensured reliable feedback and a consistent experience during testing.
projects.reflection: This project taught me how powerful gesture-based interactions can be when designed thoughtfully. The key takeaway was that reducing friction doesn't mean reducing clarity—both can be achieved simultaneously through careful iteration and user testing.

projects.title: Exploitation by Design
projects.alt: Research-based case study on dark patterns in social media interfaces
projects.description: A research-driven UX case study investigating how dark patterns in social media mobile applications manipulate user behavior and undermine user autonomy. Download the full thesis in Swedish.
projects.fullDescription: An in-depth UX research project examining the prevalence of dark patterns in popular social media mobile applications. The study analyzes how interface design is used to steer user behavior, capture attention, and exploit psychological vulnerabilities, often at the expense of user autonomy.
projects.challenges: Social media platforms are deeply embedded in everyday life, yet their interfaces often employ manipulative design strategies that users are unaware of. The challenge was to systematically identify and categorize dark patterns across multiple platforms, while translating academic research into insights relevant for design practice.
projects.solution: I conducted a structured interface audit of nine widely used social media mobile applications. Interactions were documented through screen recordings and analyzed using thematic analysis, guided by an established dark pattern ontology. The findings were synthesized into higher-level design strategies illustrating how user autonomy is undermined.
projects.outcome: The study identified 34 unique dark patterns, 13 of which were newly defined. The results highlight recurring design strategies such as obstruction, forced action, and social engineering. The project demonstrates how persuasive design techniques can shift from supporting user goals to exploiting attention, behavior, and psychological vulnerability.
projects.reflection: This research deepened my understanding of how design decisions compound over time. It reinforced my commitment to ethical design practices and the importance of questioning design patterns that might serve business goals at the expense of user autonomy.

projects.title: Website for Billig Bokföring
projects.description: A clean, user-friendly website for Billig Bokföring, a Swedish bookkeeping service targeting businesses and freelancers. The site emphasizes clarity and ease of navigation, providing essential information about services, pricing, and contact options.

projects.title: Fullstack E-commerce Website for naima
projects.description: A modern, accessible fullstack web application for Naima, a Swedish superfood fika brand. The site combines brand storytelling with e-commerce functionality, featuring an interactive retailer map, wholesale partner dashboard, and comprehensive product showcase.
projects.fullDescription: Detailed multi-paragraph description for the project detail page. A modern, accessible fullstack web application for Naima, a Swedish superfood fika brand. The site combines brand storytelling with e-commerce functionality, featuring an interactive retailer map, wholesale partner dashboard, and comprehensive product showcase.
projects.challenges: The main challenge was creating a dual-purpose platform that served both B2C customers looking for products and B2B wholesale partners needing account management. Additionally, integrating a dynamic retailer map while maintaining fast load times required careful optimization.
projects.solution: I implemented a modular component architecture using React and Zustand for state management, allowing seamless switching between customer and wholesale views. For the retailer map, I used lazy loading and optimized API calls. The backend was built with Node.js and MongoDB to handle user authentication, product management, and wholesale orders efficiently.
projects.outcome: The website successfully launched with positive feedback from both customers and wholesale partners. Load times stayed under 2 seconds, the retailer map increased store visits by 30%, and the wholesale portal streamlined B2B operations significantly.

projects.title: Portfolio
projects.description: You're looking at it. This is a showcase of user-centered design in action.

projects.title: Happy Thoughts
projects.description: A feel-good full-stack app where users can share positive thoughts and like each other’s messages. Built with React and Vite on the frontend, and Node.js with Express and MongoDB on the backend. The app features dynamic updates via a REST API, responsive design, and real-time message interaction.

projects.title: Screamflix
projects.alt: Screenshot of Screamflix horror movie browser
projects.description: Together with Cathi, I created Screamflix, a curated archive that lets users explore horror films by decade. The design and concept were inspired by the aesthetics of classic horror, and the goal was to offer a fun and slightly spooky way to browse cult classics and hidden gems.

projects.title: Weather App
projects.alt: Screenshot of weather app showing current conditions
projects.description: A responsive web-based application that fetches real-time weather data through API integration. Focused on a clear user flow and modern design.
